title: From RStudio to Published Paper: Writing Manuscripts with Quarto
text:
Most researchers today already use R and RStudio for their data analysis. We run models, generate tables, and produce figures, all within the same environment.
But when it comes to writing the actual manuscript, we often switch tools: exporting results to Word, formatting references in citation managers, or handing over LaTeX code to journals. This adds friction, duplication, and errors.
The question is: why leave RStudio when you can write your manuscript there too?
With Quarto, you can now write your entire paper in RStudio, combining:

Your text and manuscript structure.

Your code chunks (R, Python, Julia, etc).

Figures and tables, perfectly placed and automatically updated.

References and citations handled automatically.

Multiple output formats (Word, PDF, HTML) in one click.

It’s a single, reproducible workflow: from data to manuscript.

title: From RStudio to Published Paper: Writing Manuscripts with Quarto
section: Getting Started with Quarto in RStudio
text:
Getting Started with Quarto in RStudio
You don’t need a new tool. Quarto comes as part of RStudio (Posit IDE).
To create a manuscript:

In RStudio, go to: File → New Project.

Select New Directory → Quarto Manuscript.

Give your project a name (e.g., my-paper) and choose where to save it.

RStudio will create a dedicated project folder containing all the necessary Quarto files for your manuscript.

Your project will have:
my-paper/
├── index.qmd        # Main manuscript file
├── references.bib   # Bibliography file
├── _quarto.yml      # Project settings
└── figures/         # Store your figures here

title: From RStudio to Published Paper: Writing Manuscripts with Quarto
text:
Writing Your Manuscript
The index.qmd file is where you write your paper. It looks like this:
---
title: "My Research Paper"
author: "Your Name"
date: "2025-09-20"
format:
  pdf: default
  docx: default
  html: default
bibliography: references.bib
---

# Abstract

A short summary of your work.

# Introduction

Why this research matters...

# Methods


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
# Example R code included in the paper
library(ggplot2)
ggplot(mtcars, aes(wt, mpg)) + geom_point()
```
:::


# Results

Here is where the code-generated figure will appear.

# Discussion

Interpret your findings.

# References
👉 Notice how code and narrative are written side by side. When you render the manuscript, the figure produced by ggplot2 is automatically inserted, formatted, and captioned.

title: From RStudio to Published Paper: Writing Manuscripts with Quarto
text:
Adding References
Quarto uses a references.bib file (BibTeX format). Example entry:
@article{smith2020,
  title={Data Science in Healthcare},
  author={Smith, John and Doe, Jane},
  journal={Journal of Health Analytics},
  year={2020},
  volume={12},
  number={3},
  pages={123-135}
}
In your manuscript, cite it like this:
Research in this field is expanding rapidly [@smith2020].
At the end, Quarto automatically generates the bibliography.
Want APA style? Add this to the YAML:
csl: apa.csl
(Download styles from Zotero’s style repository).

title: From RStudio to Published Paper: Writing Manuscripts with Quarto
text:
Rendering Your Paper
In RStudio, click the Render button (or run quarto render in the terminal).
This generates:

Word document (index.docx) — ready to share with supervisors or collaborators.

PDF (index.pdf) — beautifully typeset.

HTML (index.html) — great for online publishing or lab websites.

All from the same source file.

Here’s why you’ll never want to go back once you try it:

Stay in RStudio, where your data, code, and writing already live.

One source = many outputs: Word for co-authors, PDF for journals, HTML for web.

Code and figures update automatically: no more broken copy-paste.

References are automatic: stop fighting citation managers.

Reproducibility built in: others can rerun your analysis and regenerate the manuscript.

text:

Most research is already done in R and RStudio — so why not finish the journey there too?
With Quarto Manuscript, you can analyze, write, and publish all in one place. Your papers become reproducible, polished, and effortless to export into any format required by journals.
Start with your next section, add your figures inline, and let Quarto handle the formatting and references. Writing a paper will feel less like a formatting chore, and more like a natural extension of your research.

Status: Under peer review


This project explores global researcher mobility and collaboration in mental health by combining author origin data with advanced bibliometric and network analysis. It reveals hidden collaboration clusters, key talent flows, and patterns of brain drain and retention to inform equitable talent policies and strengthen international research partnerships.





Status:

By creating informative metrics to assess whether research volume aligns with mortality data, it identifies gaps and mismatches, highlighting where research priorities diverge from health needs and informing strategic funding and global health planning.

title: How I Can Help
Beat Procrastination and Write Research Papers Faster
text:
Want to beat procrastination and draft faster?
Here are some of the most effective tips I’ve gathered that truly work.



Stop editing as you write! Your first draft is about getting ideas down, not grammar or polish.

Editing too early wastes time and fuels procrastination.

Save grammar, clarity, and formatting for later rounds.

✅ Perfectionism = procrastination. A rough draft builds clarity and momentum.




Here’s a plan that simplifies writing and saves time:

Structure first: Outline using your target journal’s template.

Write key sections first (Methods, Results).

Intro/Abstract last: they’ll be sharper once your content is final.

Draft fast: Aim for 1 section/day. Quarto’s dynamic formatting/code tools remove friction.

Revise after drafting: Polishing a full draft is faster and more motivating than fixing fragments.






Perfectionism slows you down — draft first, polish later.

Writing a rough Version 0 clears mental blocks and creates momentum.

Quarto Manuscript helps you stay focused on ideas, not formatting.


💡 Want to try these methods? Start with your next project: create a Quarto outline, commit to Version 0, and watch how much faster your draft grows.

Thanks for stopping by! Hope you found something useful :)
